I believe the word you intended was "pathetic".

As for PDFs, I use Pages from iWorks '9 on a Mac for any fancy document editing, for plain text documents I only do markdown and there's a lot of OSS out there to convert from markdown to PDFs but I don't recall ever having the need to do so. Pandoc [1] has always looked promising though.

For writing ebooks, I use GitBook [2]. You could also write ebooks in Pandoc

[1] http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/
[2] https://www.gitbook.io/
Yes Kameradschaft, lurking in the shadows of the interwebz stalking your typos. #CreepLVL: #SpellingNazi :D

You didn't mention that Acrobat takes a lot of processing power for nothing, literally.
I tried an open source viewer called Sumatra PDF, it's very lightweight application and it loads almost instantly, renders pages extremely quickly,but as it's a free application expect some pitfalls and crashes.
Another option will be Foxit or PDF-Xchange they are both the same and each one coasts around $30 for the pro version, but personally i prefer PDF-Xchange, i used the free basic version with basic functionality that outpaces the basic functionality of Acrobat.
It loads fairly quick, and you can perform simple page annotations with drawings and text.
